Award.AwardTitle: SBE: Small: An Analysis of the Relationship Between Cyberaggression and Self-Disclosure among Diverse Youths

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Youths of the digital age live parallel lives online and in the real world, frequently disclosing personal information to cyberfriends and strangers, regardless of race, class or gender. Race and gender do make a difference, however, when these online disclosures lead to acts of cyberaggression. The PIs' previous work revealed that some youths are resistant to cyberaggression and that there are differences in perceptions of cyberbullying among youths from different cultural and racial backgrounds. This research aims to explore the relationship between youths' self-disclosures, cultural backgrounds, and their perceptions of cyberaggression.

The PIs conduct a longitudinal, interdisciplinary study that builds upon their ongoing cyberaggression pattern recognition research by: 1) using surveys and focus groups to test and refine their theories about self-disclosure, perception, cultural difference, and cyberaggression communication patterns, 2) using machine learning to develop detection and response technologies for use in applications designed to protect youths, 3) using focus groups to evaluate the applications, and 4) making the data collected from this project available to the research community. This work is important to understand the role of self-disclosure in cybervictmization among youths, and provides the theoretical groundwork for the development of effective response strategies that can be employed by youths when they are attacked online. The data from this study will provide a rich source of material for other researchers in both computer science and in the social and behavior sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Youths today are digital natives who live parallel lives on the Internet and in the real world, regularly disclosing personal information to friends and strangers in their online social networks.  Unfortunately, such personal disclosures can change from socially constructive to destructive, from innocent chats to cyberbullying and Internet sexual predation. Youths' comfort with self-disclosure online exposes them to exploitation.  

Our previous work identified noticeable differences in teens' communication styles that appeared to make some youths resistant to cyberaggression. Furthermore, there were signals which indicated that youths of color do not perceive of cyberbullying the same way as white youths. Furthermore, most of the data used to study cyberbullying and Internet predation are incomplete or inauthentic in some way.  Previous research rarely shows the diversity of youths who are impacted by cyberbullying, the diversity of youth perspectives on cyberbullying, or even authentic youth voices engaged in cyberbullying or cyberbullying-related practices.   The project responded to these noticeable gaps in the literature, by speaking with youths directly about their experiences, and capturing a large corpus of authentic communication to/from youth, ages 10-14.

We surveyed youths to determine the relationship between their online self-disclosure practices and their cyberbullying experiences, finding significant correlation between cyberbullying and the amount and type of information disclosed online. Our findings confirm that youths who report lower self-disclosure rates also report fewer cyberbullying experiences.  Our data show racial/ethnic differences in self-disclosure behaviors, with White youths disclosing more types of personal information to more people, online and offline, than non-White youths.  Given that youth of color report lower levels of victimization among both themselves and their friends, they may be limiting disclosure as a preventative measure. 

Our focus group sessions with youth in selected subpopulations, namely LGBTQ+ youth and tweens (ages 10-15), confirmed commonly perceived psychological, social, and physical effects of cyberbullying. Furthermore, while most researchers suggest that cyberbullying needs to be intentional, these participants believed that it is possible to unknowingly cyberbully someone. In general, the tween group was sympathetic to cyberbullying victims, but also maintained empathy with the cyberbullies themselves. Our LGBTQ+ participants described instances of activity abandonment and self-censorship as a result of experiencing or witnessing cyberbullying, a result not observed in previous studies. These adolescents are actively managing their self-disclosure online, being very careful about with whom and in what way they share personal information. Our tween group went even further, by implying that it was the individual's responsibility to control their online information, so as not to open themselves up to victimization. 

Finally, to respond to the lack of available authentic data for studying youths' online communication, we deployed cell phones to 70 youth ages 10-14 and collected SMS (text messages) and social media posts for a full year, more than 800,000 messages. Our participants were assured that individual instances would never be released, and all results would be published in aggregated form only. Thus, we have developed an online password-protected system to support access to these data by other research groups.  The online system allows Boolean and Regular Expression queries and will aggregate the data by any combination of gender, race, hour of the day, and day of the week.  Access will be granted to qualified research teams by request to the PIs.  It is our hope, and the hope of the study participants, that this system will result in a better understanding of youth behavior on social media and via text messaging, and ultimately result in safer and more enjoyable online experience.
